title: VFX in JoJo Rabbit
credit_line:
VFX Supervisor: Brendan Seals
Courtesy Luma Pictures and Fox Searchlight Pictures
brief_description: Visual effects studio Luma Pictures helped Taika Waititi realise his creative vision for Jojo Rabbit by replacing contemporary elements in scenes with period-accurate ones that represent WWII Germany.

constellations_primary.name: Undercutting extremism with absurdity
constellations_primary.description: Taika Waititi's satirical performance as Adolf Hitler in Jojo Rabbit connects to a number of other portrayals that includes ill-fated (and conceived) TV shows, memes, high camp and cinema classics.

description: The world through a child’s eyes is a unique thing, even more so when that child is created by Academy Award-nominee Taika Waititi. Visual effects studio Luma Pictures helped Waititi realise his creative vision for Jojo Rabbit. Luma Pictures took street scenes filmed in the present-day Czech Republic and made them more historically appropriate for World War II Germany. Removing contemporary elements and replacing them with period-accurate ones is subtle work, but it helps weave the tapestry of Jojo’s reality: both real and imagined.
